title-group.article-title: Health situation and perceived health status among women experiencing homelessness: A longitudinal study in Spain

author-notes.corresp: *CorrespondenceJosé Juan Vázquez, PhD, Universidad de Alcalá, Área de Psicología Social, Aulario María de Guzmán, C/ San Cirilo, s/n 28801 Alcalá de Henares, Madrid, Spain.Email: jj.vazquez@uah.es

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2022 The Authors. Public Health Nursing published by Wiley Periodicals LLC.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The paper analyses the health situation and the perceived health status of a sample of women experiencing homelessness (n = 138) in Madrid, Spain. All participants were adults, and the night before the baseline interview, they had slept on the street, at a shelter or any facility provided to care for people living homeless. The information was collected using structured interviews, repeated twice a year for a 3‐year follow‐up period. The findings of this study show that women experiencing homelessness presented poor health, particularly in comparison with the general Spanish population. Over half of the women questioned claimed to have a diagnosed serious or chronic illness, with a correlation between these conditions and the age, time spent homeless or high levels of drug use. There was a positive correlation found between women's perceived health status and being younger and having access to independent accommodation, while having suffered a number of stressful life events and having spent long periods of time living homeless presented a negative correlation with a good perceived health status.

p.mixed-citation: Lenta, M., Panadero, S., Cabrera, A., & Vázquez, J. J. (2023). Health situation and perceived health status among women experiencing homelessness: A longitudinal study in Spain. Public Health Nursing, 40, 9–16. 10.1111/phn.1313036029140PMC10086823

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: People experiencing homelessness reflect one of the most extreme example of the worldwide phenomenon of poverty and social exclusion (Guillén et al., 2020; Suarez et al., 2018; Vázquez et al., 2017) and, of those people, women are particularly vulnerable in a number of ways (Vázquez et al., 2019a), with their own set of circumstances and backgrounds, usually differing from those of their male counterparts (Aldridge et al., 2018). Unfortunately, women tend to be under‐represented in research on homelessness, and the gender issues of this group are under‐researched (Bretherton, 2020; Rodríguez‐Moreno et al., 2021), despite gender analysis being a key focal point in the field of public health, in order to understand social inequities and inequalities in health (Hankivsky et al., 2018). According to Winetrobe et al. (2017), the consideration of the excluded population as a homogeneous group limits the development of appropriate health and social security policies.

A number of authors (e.g., Hatch & Dohrenwend, 2007; Vázquez et al., 2017) have pointed out that economic factors are not the only one impacting the situation of people experiencing homelessness. In this regard, health problems seem to play a relevant role in the sliding into homelessness and remaining in this situation (Caton et al., 2005; Greenberg & Rosenheck, 2008), as well as in the processes of become homeless again having had access to independent accommodation (Aubry et al., 2012; Roca et al., 2019). In terms of the health of people experiencing homelessness, a range of studies point towards the existence of high mortality rates among the homeless population (Hwang et al., 2009), some suggesting a higher risk among women (Nordentoft & Wandall‐Holm, 2003; Nusselder et al., 2013).

Likewise, remaining homeless poses a major threat to health (Aubry et al., 2012; Ropers & Boyer, 1987) as it aggravates existing conditions, delays recovery and can cause new illnesses (Schanzer et al., 2007). Also, serious illnesses seem to be connected with long‐term homelessness, meaning that people with serious and/or chronic health conditions will remain in that situation for longer periods (Parker, 2010). People who spend long periods living homeless and also suffer from health issues are at a greater risk of suffering particularly negative health consequences for other reasons, such as the prevalence of substance abuse and limited access to preventive healthcare (Parker, 2010).

A number of studies show that people experiencing homelessness tend to be in a poor state of health, which are particularly serious in the case of women. Women experiencing homelessness tend to present more chronic physical health conditions than their male counterparts (Gawron et al., 2017; Montgomery et al., 2017; Vuillermoz et al., 2017). In the US, for example, Winetrobe et al. (2017) reported that more women living homeless suffered with diagnosed chronic physical health conditions than men and Montgomery et al. (2017) found that a larger proportion of women suffered from chronic medical conditions than men. In Sweden, Beijer and Andréasson (2009) found that people living homeless had twice the risk of being hospitalized than the general population, with the younger homeless women being most likely to be taken into hospital, principally for skin infections linked to increased exposure to excessive consumption of psychoactive substances and poor hygiene. In France, Vuillermoz et al. (2017) stated that 25% of the women living homeless interviewed had suffered at least one untreated healthcare requirement in the year prior to the interview. Along the same lines, in a country with a low level of income such as Nicaragua, Vázquez et al. (2020) observed that the poor health condition of homeless people was particularly negative among women.

In Spain, Muñoz et al. (2004) noted that the perception of health among people experiencing homelessness (52.9% good vs. 30.7% poor) was worse than among people at risk ‐ who used public services but still had their homes – (69.8% good vs. 20.0% poor) and general population (68.8% good vs. 15.2% poor). The Spanish Institute of National Statistics (INE, 2018), found that 70.4% of Spanish women perceived their health status to be good, 21.0% said it was fair and 8.5% said it was poor. INE (2018) also indicated that 68.2% of Spanish women suffered from a chronic or long‐term illness or health condition. The main issues of this nature that had been medically diagnoses in Spanish women over 15 were chronic back pain (lumbar) (23.5%), chronic back pain (cervical) (21.5%), high blood pressure (20.0%), high cholesterol (17.8%), migraines or frequent headaches (13.6%) or diabetes (7.1%),

In Spain, the situation of women experiencing homelessness is understudied, and no longitudinal studies of this kind have been conducted. However, it is important to obtain data focusing on specific environments, as the extrapolation of findings to different setting can be problematic. Among other issues, this is because of differences across countries in terms of systems and access to healthcare, the scope of social protection networks, climate, the concentration of extreme poverty in urban areas or the makeup of socially excluded groups. The purpose of this work is to contribute to the study of health among women experiencing homelessness in Madrid, and how their health evolves over time. The results obtained will provide information to be taken into consideration for the design and roll‐out of healthcare policies, health services and gender‐based care schemes for the homeless.

sec.title: METHOD
sec.p: The study was carried out based on data collected from a sample of women experiencing homelessness (n = 138), interviewed in Madrid, Spain. All participants were over 18, and the night before the initial interview they had slept on the street, at a shelter or at another homeless facility. The main characteristics of the women interviewed are listed in Table 1.

caption.p: Characteristics of women experiencing homelessness interviewed in Madrid, Spain

tr.td: Separated de facto without legal procedures
Age when they become homeless (M years, SD)

td.bold: Number of times homeless during their life
In the past month s/he has slept…

sec.p: Participants were recruited in shelters and drop‐in homeless centers, as well as on the street and in public areas. The information (both at baseline and follow‐up) was collected using structured interview, which solved any potential issues with reading and/or comprehension. The structured interview used was a version with a gender perspective of an instrument used in previous studies for people experiencing homelessness in Madrid, which was adapted to the fact that the interviewees were women. The first structured interview collected information on 1227 variables and lasted between 45 and 80 min. The follow‐up interviews were shorter – lasting around 30–60 min, and focused on the issues most likely to have changed over the period. The interviews were conducted by four interviewers with experience in researches of similar characteristics. Data were recorded and coded by the interviewers. The purpose of the study was explained to the women they were asked to provide informed consent and personal data before completing the interview, as well as permission for researchers to contact them by mobile phone, social media or third parties.

During the follow‐up period, participants were contacted regularly, with the support of institutions and organizations working with people experiencing homelessness and with the collaboration of friends of the interviewees, neighbors, service users and social workers. Personal contact with the participants was maintained on a regular basis in the street and in the care facilities and, when possible, the participants were contacted by mobile phone, WhatsApp or social media. Conducting follow‐up interviews sometimes required travel to different parts of Spain. Some interviews with participants who had returned to their country of origin were conducted by telephone or via internet (Skype, WhatsApp…). The interviewees did not receive any incentive for their participation in the initial interview or in the first two follow‐up interviews (6 and 12 months after the initial interview). The follow‐up interviews conducted 18, 24, and 36 months after the baseline interview were incentivized with a voucher (worth 20 euros) exchangeable for products in supermarkets.

Ethical approval was granted by the appropriate Institutional Review Board. All initial information was collected over the course of a calendar year, and the follow‐up interviews were conducted at intervals of 6, 12, 18, 24, and 36 months after that. Of the 138 women originally interviewed, it was possible to interview 92 women after 6 months, 85 women after 12 months, 82 women after 18 months, 73 women after 24 months, and 67 women after 36 months. At 36 months follow‐up period, 33.8% of the women could not be located and 8.8% declined to be interviewed. In addition, we verified that three women returned to their country of origin and eight died. Throughout the 3‐years follow‐up period, the mean age of the interviewees, the mean time living homeless, and the mean age at which they first found themselves living homeless remained relatively constant. Also, the respondents’ educational background and their perceived health status remained relatively constant during follow‐up period. However, after 3‐years follow‐up period a decrease in the percentage of women with foreign nationality was observed, but we consider that this variation does not have a significant impact on the results obtained in the study.

The database was created, and data processed using the SPSS statistical analysis and data management system 21.0. When making comparisons, the χ 2 “Chi square” statistic was used for nominal variables, and the “Student t test for independent samples” was used for continuous variables. The Stata.14 programme was used to complete an ordered logistic regression analysis, in order to identify the effect of different factors on the participants’ perceived health condition both at baseline and at follow up. The ordered logistic regression model included “Perceived health” as a dependent variable. This variable was measured on a Likert scale ranging from 1 to 5, where 1 was “a very poor perceived health” and 5 was “very good perceived health”. Table 2 shows the explanatory variables included in the model, together with a brief description of each.

caption.p: Variables included in the logistic regression model

tr.td: Homeless for more than five years
Time homeless more than 60 months (at baseline)
Access to an independent accommodation at follow‐up
Suffering intimate partner violence at follow‐up
Feeling of loneliness or abandonment (at follow up)
Number of stressful vital events suffered
Number of stressful vital events suffered over lifetime (at baseline)

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: As shown in Table 3, 41.2% of the women experiencing homelessness had a good perception of their overall state of health (Good or Very Good) at baseline, versus 26.5% who considered their state of health to be bad (Poor or Very Poor). The baseline percentages are very similar to the ones observed after 36 months of follow‐up, showing that 3 years after the first interview, 38.8% considered their state of health to be good (Good or Very Good) versus 25.3% who considered their state of health to be bad (Poor or Very Poor). At baseline, 27% of the participants considered that their state of health had worsened over the previous year, compared to 40% who felt that their health had improved over the same period. These percentages are very similar to those reported by the women when interviewed after 36 months.

caption.p: Perceived state of health at the time of the first interview (baseline) and after 3 years of follow‐up (36 months) among women experiencing homelessness in Madrid, Spain

td.bold: Perception of the evolution of general state of health during 12 months prior to the interview

sec.p: The results of the logistic regression analysis indicate that being younger and having had access to independent accommodation during follow‐up have a positive correlation with perceived state of health. These variables have the greatest impact on how the women interviewed saw their own state of health. At the same time, the number of stressful life events suffered and having spent more than 5 years living homeless at baseline, as well as reporting having suffered intimate partner violence during follow‐up and having had feelings of loneliness or abandonment correlated negatively with a positive perceived state of health.

53.7% (73) of the women interviewed reported suffering a medically diagnosed severe or chronic illness. The interviewees who stated that they had a diagnosed severe or chronic illness had been homeless (the sum of all periods of homelessness over the course of their lifetime) for an average of 101.0 months (SD = 108.45), a significantly higher figure that the 46.4 months (SD = 53.95) for those who had not been diagnosed with a serious or chronic disease (t (99.374) −3.643; p = .000).

As shown in Table 4, in the month prior to the baseline interviews and at 36 months follow‐up, around two thirds of those interviewed reported suffering physical pain or discomfort. 36.7% stated that in the month prior to the baseline interview they had suffered severe or extreme pain. After 3 years, the percentage of women who reported severe or extreme pain during the month prior to the interview was very similar (37.9%). Also, as can be seen in Table 5, the illnesses or ailments reported by the largest proportion of women were back pain, injuries resulting from accidents, bronchitis, headaches, asthma and/or hypertension, although some of these had not been diagnosed at the time of the interview. Although to a lesser extent, other severe illnesses (i.e., HIV/AIDS, cancer, osteoporosis, cirrhosis of the liver and/or epilepsy) were also suffered by a significant percentage of the women interviewed.

caption.p: Logistic regression model. Factors influencing perceived state of health in women experiencing homelessness in Madrid, Spain

tr.td: Number of stressful vital events suffered

caption.p: Suffering of physical pain or discomfort during the month prior to the first interview (baseline) and the month prior to the 3‐year follow‐up interview (36 months), and ailments or diseases diagnosed over the course of the women's lives and active at the time of the first interview (baseline) among women experiencing homelessness in Madrid, Spain

td.bold: Suffering of physical pain or discomfort during the 4 weeks prior to the interview
Degree of physical pain or discomfort during the 4 weeks prior to the interview

th.bold: Suffered at the time of the interview (n = 138)

tr.td: Permanent injuries or damage due to accident
Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism or other hormonal disorders
Any sexually transmitted disease (gonorrhoea, syphilis, chlamydia…) (except HIV/AIDS)

sec.p: With regard to the greater prevalence of pain or illness at the time of the first interview, statistically significant differences were observed depending on age, time living homeless and having abused drugs at some point in life. Thus, the women reporting chronic back pain tended to be older (47.7 years (SD = 9.65) vs. 43.5 years (SD = 12.42); t (132.568) = −2.215; p = .028) and had taken more drugs at some point in their life (57.1% (28) vs. 39.3% (33); χ 2 (1) = 3.975, p = .046; φ = .173). The participants suffering permanent injuries or damage due to an accident tended to have been experiencing homelessness for longer (in total), 105.8 months (SD = 106.01) versus 58.6 months (SD = 77.43) (t (70.540) = −6.622; p = .011), and were more likely to have taken drugs at some point in their life ((54.0% (27) vs. 25.0% (21); χ 2 (1) = 11.466, p = .001; φ = .293). The interviewees suffering from bronchitis were of a higher average age (49.6 years (SD = 9.14) vs. 44.2 years (SD = 11.84); t (69.379) = −2.698; p = .009). The participants suffering from migraines or frequent headaches had taken more drugs at some point in their life (56.0% (28) vs. 26.5% (22); χ 2 (1) = 11.570, p = .001; φ = .295). The interviewees suffering from asthma tended to have been experiencing homelessness for longer (in total) (108.7 months (SD = 102.04) vs. 63.8 months (SD = 84.43); t (124) = −2.491; p = .014) and were more likely to have abused drug at some point in their life (38.0% (19) vs. 20.2% (17); χ 2 (1) = 5.033, p = .025; φ = .194), and the women reporting to have HIV/ AIDS had been homeless for a longer time on average (in total) (128.0 months (SD = 124.94) vs. 65.5 months (SD = 80.26); t (22.050) = −2.154; p = .042) and were more likely to have abused drugs at some point in their lives (34.0% (17) vs. 4.8% (4); χ 2 (1) = 19.565, p = .000; φ = 389).

sec.title: DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The results obtained in this study suggest that only 41% of women experiencing homelessness interviewed in Madrid perceived their state of health to be good. This is well below the 70% of women in the Spanish population in general (INE, 2018). In this regard, the percentage of women interviewed (with an average age of 45) who considered their health to be good was lower than the percentage of Spanish women aged between 65 and 74 who perceived their state of the health to be good (48.5%) (INE, 2018). Fazel et al. (2014) observed that people experiencing homelessness tend to acquire very early‐onset age‐related functional deficiencies. Ruiz‐Coronel et al. (2019) state that the lifestyle resulting from adaptation to life on the street and the relationships that homeless people forge with their social and material environment immerses them in a rapid process of physical and psychological decline, suggesting the living homeless seems to make people grow old faster (Fazel et al., 2014; Ruiz‐Coronel et al., 2019). In this regard, different authors point out that people experiencing homelessness should have access at age around 50 to the services designed for the general population aged over 65(Brown et al., 2012; McDonald et al., 2007).

The poor perception of health condition among women experiencing homelessness is particularly evident in the fact that 26.5% of interviews claimed to be in a poor state of health, compared to the 8.5% of Spanish women overall (INE, 2018). While there seems to be a tendency among people experiencing homelessness to positively overestimate their health condition (Ruiz‐Coronel et al., 2019), this perception is negative in the case of women in this situation. Also, as observed by Vuillermoz et al. (2017) in women experiencing homelessness in Paris, a poor perception of health was associated to unmet healthcare needs. It is worth noting that over 3 years of follow‐up, the participants’ perceived health situation was consistent with that reported at baseline, meaning their perception of their own health condition was consistent over time.

The younger participants and, in particular, those who accessed independent accommodation during the 3‐year follow‐up period, tended to have a better perceived state of health. Access to independent housing, and its consequent lifestyle implications, appears as one of the most relevant variables for a positive perception of health condition. So, for people experiencing homelessness with significant health issues it would be appropriate to include them on care schemes that include housing with support (Nelson et al., 2007). Providing access to housing, together with intensive health, social and community care, has proven to be effective in overcoming the homeless situation (Tsemberis et al., 2004).

Meanwhile a negative correlation can be seen between perceiving oneself to be in good health and suffering from a high number of stressful life events, having been the victim of intimate partner violence and remaining homeless for long periods, together with presenting feeling of loneliness or abandonment. These data largely coincide with those obtained by Bullard and Sittner (2019) and Rivas et al. (2021), who found that suffering sexual violence in childhood and intimate partner violence in adulthood were predictors of worsening physical health in women experiencing homelessness. Along the same lines, Vuillermoz et al. (2017) found that the perception of poor health correlated with victimization and depression. In the opinion of Montgomery et al. (2017) and Gawron et al. (2017), women presented a greater decline in health than men due to their increased risk of suffering violent situations. Multiple and/or severe stressful life events from an early age is linked to spending long periods of time homeless (Vázquez et al., 2019b). A number of authors have noted that remaining in a homeless situation poses a major threat to health, as it aggravates existing conditions, compromises recovery from those issues and can lead to new illnesses (Aubry, et al., 2012; Guillén et al., 2021; Muñoz et al., 2004; Ropers & Boyer, 1987; Schanzer et al., 2007). People with severe and/or chronic illness tend to remain homeless for longer (Parker, 2010). Additionally, people who have been homeless for long period of time and suffer from health issues run a far greater risk of suffering worsening health crises, due to issues such as an increase in substance use and more barriers to accessing medical services (Parker, 2010).

Around one quarter of the women interviewed in Madrid considered that their state of health had declined over the previous year, while just under half felt that their health had improved over the same period. These percentages are similar at baseline and after the 3‐year follow‐up period, suggesting a significant consistency over time. The relatively positive subjective perception of self‐health of improved health contrasts notably with the fact that around half of those interviewed reported suffering from a medically diagnosed severe or chronic condition. This matter particularly affected women who had been experiencing homelessness for the longest. Although in principle the percentage of women suffering from a serious or chronic medical condition seems high, it is actually considerably lower than the proportion of women in the general Spanish population (68%) with a long‐term or chronic illness or health condition (INE, 2018). It should be assessed whether there could be under‐diagnosis of certain conditions among women experiencing homelessness, which would be associated with the difficulties in accessing adequate healthcare (Vázquez et al., 2019a), particularly in the case of primary care.

Around two thirds of those interviewed reported have suffered physical pain or discomfort during the month immediately preceding the interview, a third of whom referred cases of severe or extreme pain. These data, similar at baseline and after 3 years of follow‐up, could be interpreted as indicative of negative health among women experiencing homelessness. The most common conditions and ailments among those interviewed were chronic back pain, headaches, accident‐related injuries, asthma, bronchitis and hypertension. Similar prevalence of some of these (e.g., hypertension, asthma) was observed by Gawron et al. (2017) among women experiencing homelessness in the US. Some of the most common ailments or illnesses among the interviewees also match the chronic or long‐term conditions most common in the general women's population in Spain (INE, 2018), with a similar prevalence of chronic back pain or hypertension among women living homeless and those who were not (INE, 2018). However, health problems such as headaches, accident‐related injuries, chronic bronchitis or asthma were more widespread in women experiencing homelessness than in the general Spanish population (INE, 2018). Prolonged periods living homeless and facing multiple and/or severe stressful life events (including the use of psychoactive substances) would help to explain the greater trend of these health problems among women experiencing homelessness. So, it can be seen that women who suffered injuries from an accident, or asthma, tended to have been on the streets for longer, and those who suffered from migraines, asthma o accident injuries, for the most part had been drug users. As reported by Ruiz‐Coronel et al. (2019) the homeless lifestyle seems to immerse these women into a rapid process of physical decline.

Women experiencing homelessness were also affected by others severe and chronic conditions, such rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis, cirrhosis, epilepsy, cancer… Special attention requires the high prevalence of HIV/AIDS amount women experiencing homelessness in Madrid, as it a chronic and very severe illness, still highly stigmatized. The percentage of women experiencing homelessness in Madrid with HIV/AIDS (15%) was fifty times higher than in the general Spanish population (0.3%) and three hundred times higher than among women in the general population (0.05%) (Unidad de Vigilancia de VIH y Comportamientos de Riesgo, 2019). Furthermore, the prevalence of HIV/AIDS found among those interviewed in Madrid was much higher than that observed among women experiencing homelessness in the US, found different researchers to be between 1% and 3% (Gawron et al., 2017; Montgomery et al., 2017). The fact that the Spanish public health sector largely offers appropriate HIV treatment for women experiencing homelessness may have had an influence on the condition no longer being a necessarily fatal condition (Deeks et al., 2013), which can help explain, in part, the high number of women experiencing homelessness in Madrid with HIV. It is noteworthy that the women interviewed in Madrid suffering from HIV/AIDS had been homeless for twice as long, and an even greater number had abused drugs. This high proportion of women experiencing homelessness with HIV could be due to the fact that the participants had a high risk of exposure to the virus (i.e., intravenous drug use, sexual assaults from an early age, intimate partner violence and other gender‐related violence, difficulties in taking precautions during sex…). In this regard, it is essential to pay particular attention and provide support to the women experiencing homelessness most exposed to these situations.

This study presents limitations, of which it is particularly notable that the information was obtained using a structured interview, without the possibility of contrasting it with other sources of information that the participants may provide. In addition, the study took place in Madrid (Spain), where the healthcare and social care system is not easily comparable with other contexts, making it difficult to generalize the results obtained. There is also a lack of previous studies on the issues dealt with in this paper, both in Madrid and in other regions or countries, and this has made it significantly difficult to compare the results with other research, thus narrowing down the understanding of the issue in question.

Madrid has sufficient health services to be able to address all the medical needs of the people experiencing homelessness correctly. However, it is essential to remove the barriers that are making it difficult for people experiencing homelessness to access the medical service: for example, ignorance of location and access procedures, insufficient knowledge of health issues, lack of social skills, mental health problems, substance use… In order to do this, it would be necessary to roll out street outreach teams and gender‐sensitive homeless support that prioritizes access to primary care. Healthcare services should be aware of the environmental conditions in which homeless people live, and adapt their management of chronic conditions accordingly (Fazel et al., 2014; Hwang et al., 2013).

As found by Fazel et al. (2014), a relevant political initiative would be to set targets relating to the health of people experiencing homelessness for national and regional healthcare plans, including differential gender‐specific considerations. People experiencing homelessness with health problems should be provided with coverage of their basic needs (i.e., accommodation, medication, appropriate food, etc.) from a gender perspective, thus facilitating proper treatment, recovery and rehabilitation. Health care and services for homeless men and women should also bear in mind the effect of different functional limitations identified, and anticipate their onset at earlier ages than are normally identified in the general population (Fazel et al., 2014). Health professionals should be able to detect cognitive impairment, mobility issues, urinary incontinence or falls in homeless adults aged 50 and over (Brown et al., 2012). Finally, an improvement in the health of the socially vulnerable would impact the prevention of the slide into homelessness, making it easier to overcome this situation and, overall, it would mean an improvement in the quality of life for those experiencing homelessness.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: No potential competing interest was reported by the authors.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: Data available on request from the authors.
